facts.text: The first trains were powered by steam over 200 years ago!
Train tracks are called railways or railroads.
Some trains can go really fast—faster than a cheetah!
Animals like elephants helped move train cars long ago.
Trains cross big bridges, long tunnels, and mountains!
Trains helped make time zones so people knew the time.
Some trains say “choo-choo” with their steam whistle.
Japan’s bullet trains are super speedy and called Shinkansen.
Trains can be pulled by engines or pushed from behind.
Maglev trains float above tracks using magnets—no wheels!
There are trains on every continent except Antarctica.
Toy trains are made to look like real trains and run on tracks.
Commuter trains take people to work and school every day.
They stop at many stations to pick up passengers.
Commuter trains usually run on electricity.
People sit or stand inside while the train moves fast.
These trains help many people travel without cars.
Commuter trains run on special tracks called railways.
They have many doors to let people get on and off quickly.
Some commuter trains go underground called subways.
Trains can be long with many cars connected together.
They help reduce traffic and pollution in cities.
People use tickets to ride commuter trains.
Commuter trains are very important for busy towns and cities.
Freight trains carry things like toys, food, and cars.
They are very long and heavy.
Freight trains help move stuff across the country.
They pull many big cars full of goods.
Freight trains don’t usually carry people.
These trains help stores get new things to sell.
Freight trains can carry coal, wood, and machines.
They move slowly but carry lots of heavy stuff.
Freight trains run on tracks like all other trains.
They have big engines to pull heavy loads.
Sometimes you see freight trains at railroad crossings.
Freight trains help keep stores stocked with things we need.
